DOC.HEAD: Relatives Begin Identifying Victims
DOC.TEXT: Grieving relatives flew to the northern coastal town of Kempsey on Saturday to identify the 36 victims of Australia's worst highway accident. Friday's head-on collision between two buses left 39 people injured, some trapped in wreckage for hours, and led to renewed calls to reduce the speed limit for buses and trucks from 68 mph to 56 mph. The cause of the crash was not known but newspaper reports suggested one bus veered into the oncoming lane of the two-way highway linking the cities of Sydney and Brisbane. Ten people were still hospitalized, and critically hurt were airlifted to Sydney, 280 miles south, Kempsey Hospital official Michael Doyle said. At least three foreign tourists were among the victims. Police said they came from the United States, New Zealand and Britain but their identities and hometowns were witheld pending identification and notification of relatives.
